Dear Gov. Walker,

When you delivered your stirring message about a small federal government to your colleagues in Washington, did you happen to remind them that the Dept. of Defense is part of the federal government? Maybe on your next visit? Thanks!

Contrary to what Walker seems to think, the new administration under Potus 45 is about EXPANDING the power of the federal government, not reducing it.  This will almost inevitably result in a bigger government, not a smaller one. His lust for power is unbounded.  Look at the proposals.  #1 more military.  #2 More border protection.

An educational and disturbing article. I read this with my sweet chubby baby asleep on my chest, very aware of the world's disparities. I wish there was a direct payment system to help those teachers- I would happily pay some of their (ridiculously meager) salaries. But clearly you can't have Venmo when it's too dangerous and expensive to even be able to purchase a mobile phone. Heartbreaking.
Venmo? Looked it up.  Ah.  Venmo=PayPal=Breitbart WH support.  Americans and their chubby babies benefit from neocolonialism. Sad.
How about if we take all the energy time and money from trying to colonize Mars and get busy here on planet Earth?
Thank you for highlighting this monumental tragedy and I hope the coverage will stay on the front pages until the crisis is under control. Feed these people!

This same story has been written over the decades.  Another troubled African nation torn apart by wars that no one can explain or understand.  Famine and disease consuming the continent.  Criminals in charge stealing the generosity from the West.  What can be done to help that hasn't already been tried?
"the generosity from the West" , WOW
Say OIL!

In the article he speaks of tribal and ethnic trouble, not religious trouble. Why would people in Texas care if South Sudan had oil, we've got plenty of our own. So instead of using the profits as they were designed the leading politicians stole it and leave their people to suffer. Yes, you never see that happening anywhere else except in Christian majority nations. I'm not a Christian and can see how silly and unhelpful your attitude is.

This is the story of the curse of oil. I am blessed for not being born into a shred of oil wealth. The ideal state is to be like Norway, Canada or the US which have enough oil to not be totally dependent on despotic regimes but not so much oil that there is sufficient motivation for the greedy to turn the country into a despotic regime. I'm sure ethnic strife in itself is a motivator, but it appears to be made much worse because there is oil for the wealthy to horde amongst their own tribesman. Where there are vast reserves of the black gold, dictators focus on siphoning wealth from the nation. The rival tribes focus on ousting the dictators so they can be the ones siphoning the wealth instead. And bloodshed ensues, constantly. It is the story of Iraq as well.

The solution is to develop enough technology so that world can run on clean energy. If we don't depend on oil to run cars, we solve several problems-

1) Our forced relationship with terrible regimes like Saudi Arabia
2) We solve part of the air pollution problem
3) We help the ordinary people of South Sudan see a chance at peace.

Of all the articles in today's NY Times (including North Korea and "what if"), this is by far the most horrible, tragic and disconcerting.

The worst part is virtually no one does anything of consequence to help. If I knew how (and I don't mean to simply give money), I would. I will.

And, the only reason people don't is because of skin color. My heart is broken for what people in South Sudan and the like have endured, and continue to do so.

People in the US (myself included) take so much for granted it makes me sick to my stomach. We quibbling and text and tweet over the most insignificant issues is what we do best.

All the while, this true horror of genocide and worse is occurring is the worst thing.

If you can't think of anything to do that would help, don't blame the lack of help of the color of their skin.

This is an intractable problem. If the UN can't help, and the African Union can't help, there is probably no way we can help. Certainly not by providing arms to one group or another, or handing money to one group or another.

This article says that the US has pumped $11 billion into South Sudan.  The population is only about 12 million.   That is enough to give each person a substantial startup donation.  Would this not have been more effective?  Esp if you add in the oil revenues to pay for infrastructure.  I think foreign aid, in its current form, is not working so well.
Looks like a waste of money. Lesson learned: stay out of other countries especially if there is no reliable government. Giving money only enriches the ruling class.

Remember 'Save Darfur'? All the actors coming out for intervention in what was then Sudan?

Western media was complicit in sensationalizing Sudan's attempts at bringing security to its southern areas and led to a Kosovo-esque partition under the threat of NATO's bombs. All over oil.

But the western media then forgot about the new South Sudan and handed the country to criminals and clowns. Now come the new calls for intervention. Problem, reaction, solution all leads to a cycle of neocolonialism and exploitation.

What country are you going to cheerlead for the destruction of next?
No matter the Act 1, or Act 2, Act 3 is always the same:murder and mayhem.

Amazing that most commentators completely forget that the west split south sudan for oil. Where is the "save darfur" outrage now?

The $11B "aid" most likely went to payoff corrupt locals to allow western companies in and for south sudan to spend on "infrastructure" built by western companies. So most of this $11B is probably in the hands of oil, infra and security companies. Rest easy, your tax money was well spent.
This is astute and needed to be said. My thanks.

The possibility of a transitional takeover probably won't happen because it would require the removal of a sitting president, which would look like a coup; the UN can't step in with a trusteeship of any sort on its own because that looks like colonialism. When the UN Security Council met in a private session recently on the famine in South Sudan -- why it was private was anyone's guess -- but the US ambassador to the UN apparently didn't come to the meeting and sent someone else from the mission instead, revealing the low priority of the US now in regard to the nation it helped birth but didn't follow through on comprehensively. Salva Kiir reportedly is available to visiting dignitaries (like UN officials) only during his sober hours of the day; the new reach of the US global gag rule carried out by Trump and Bannon means that the women who have been raped by militias will not have access to abortions or proper care. This is a war sowed by two raging men, and guess who suffers the most?

I'm heartbroken to read about what is happening in South Sudan. There was so much hope when the country was formed. Now it seems that all hope is gone.

If foreign intervention is the only solution, then the United Nations should work towards that. The rest of us should turn away from the Trump dog-and-pony show and focus on the rest of the world. Trump won't see Christmas as President. Meanwhile, people are suffering and nobody seems to care.

I'm grateful to the NY Times for bringing this story to our attention.

Foreign intervention hasn't worked that great for us has it?

Do you really think all the fear and hatred will vanish once we arrive or are we supposed to stay indefinitely...

Afghanistan, Iraq, Libya, Syra, etc. etc. etc.

" There was so much hope when the country was formed."
Hope is all over the place--fishing holes, race tracks, everywhere.
It means nothing.

Four score and seven years after the American Revolution Abraham Lincoln and Jefferson Davis conspired and cooperated in the slaughter of 600-750,000 of their fellow Americans in four years. In a nation with a tenth of our current population including 4 million enslaved Africans that is more dead Americans than in all other American wars combined. And both men are worshipped and exalted by the heirs of their fellow warriors.

Since 9/11/01 0.75% of Americans have volunteered to wear the uniform of any American armed military forces. None named Trump.

Something needs to drastically change wherein the African Union can act and have effective means to intervene and help safeguard African nations. To turn once again to the same old 'aid' and various agents who pledge to help seems shallow. What does the African press have to say about factors resulting in deadly tribal conflict? Independence of South Sudan was marked by a shaky start not to mention the doomed excitement of new nation saddled with oil as a major revenue.

C P Paul: nice !

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/God_Sees_the_Truth,_But_Waits
P.S. I am disappointed to learn of the decision that was made regarding the discontinuation.

I disagree with the many, many Times readers who advise in every comment section like this one to spend on experiences, especially foreign travel. Even for domestic travel, I would gladly take back most of what I spent (not much in today's dollars) in my twenties, trying to follow this advice. For many people, the dollars you earn in your twenties and thirties will be the easiest ones to earn. You don't know with certainty that your forties and fifties will be easy.

Instead of this cute piece, what should be on the front page is the shame of the USA-- the canceling of guaranteed pension plans by corporations, substituting 401ks. Some firms don’t even match. And millions can’t afford to put money in. Publicize the expert's warnings on the dangerous state of retiree financial security---that millions will face a life of poverty or near poverty ahead.

Tell the young how to organize politically to redress this grievance that contradicts our American ideals. Pressure the Dems too, not just the Gop.

Advice on how to pursue hobbies and the good life in retirement Is dependent on having basic necessities and security.

Old age is highly overrated. I am discovering at age 80 that 80 is the new 120. I have had severe rheumatoid arthritis for 16 years and they don't have a clue what causes it, and I can guarantee they don't have a cure. It is an auto-immune disease where your white cells are fooled into thinking your normal cells are the enemy. The treatment is to detune your immune system, and that entails risk of infection.

I am a retired colonel with 22 years of active duty followed by 24 years as a Boeing engineer. My first eight years of service was starvation wages, but now Military pay is quite good. My pensions are excellent, and as a military retiree, I and my wife are covered by Medicare and Tricare, no VA, and Tricare is god-like. TriCare is activated by enrolling in plan B of Medicare which costs us each about $100/month. We see whichever doctors we want at NO COST. Good thing because otherwise, I would have been charged 49-50 K/year for the past 15 years. I love you, Uncle Sam. Thank you, Uncle Sam, for helping me to earn 5 degrees in physics and engineering, including two MIT masters. Staying in the Air Force for a career was the best decision I ever made.

My best advice is that education is a life long requirement, but I always loved school. I did OK for a first generation American whose father started in the WV coal mines. Keep your mind active by reading. You can never know enough science and history. Try not to take religion too seriously.

Most renters today in multi-unit buildings are individually metered for electricity and/or gas, and some are individually metered for water. Of course a renter of a house will be paying utility bills. You will indirectly be paying landscaping costs in a rental or condo building, too. Cable television in a building is only a money-saver if you actually use it.

I never envisioned myself being old and experiencing degradation. I'd always assumed that life extension science would allow me to live to 200+ years or more, along with flying cars and a colony on Mars. Well, damn. Politics and wars have made sure that hasn't happened yet. I'm 65 (male) and just beginning to accept that I miss out on the really great discoveries just 'round the corner. Grrrrrr.....

Advice? Oh yes, so much advice I could give. Good stuff, basic stuff, hard earned stuff. But there's a possible problem with giving advice to younger folks.

a) Young people often resist advice from older folks. I don't know if that's a problem with the messenger, the listener or part of the genetic scheme. I didn't listen to what little advice my parents gave me. I still believe it was a problem with the messenger in that matter. Lesson: be and do better than your parents, if that's an issue at all.

b) One can share anecdotes and wisdom gained, but there are many things a person simply has to experience themselves, including mistakes, to really understand the lesson and get the wisdom.

But here are a few notes:
1. Women tend to be smarter than men. That is genetic evolution at play.

2. Dudes can be dumb as a stump. In my youth, I thought I was pretty darned smart. Now I look back and wonder what the hell I was thinking.

3. Be at peace. Know yourself. Be kind and tolerant to all. Learn to cherish diversity in people. Adopt a dog. Know that children need you.

Read Polonius's advice to Laertes.
Read Samuel Johnson's "Vanity of Human Wishes".
Cultivate Jane Austen's notion that "A mind lively and at ease, can do with seeing nothing, and can see nothing that does not answer."
Study History enough to have a go at contextualizing the present.
Remember Thoreau said "Each man is rich in proportion to the number of things he can afford to leave alone."
Remember Hendrix said "I'm the one who's got to die, when it's time for me to die, so let me live my own life, the way I want to."
Remember that love is a verb.

Life is not of us or for us: it blows through us like the wind through the trees; for us is the learning of the dance.

The best advice when I was just starting was to max out on contributions to your IRA, particularly if your employer is matching a significant amount. But I wasn't saddled with enormous college debt. Now, I'd look at the interest rate on my debt, compare it to the effective interest rate on (matched) contributions to an IRA, and put any discretionary income into whichever has the bigger payoff.

The very notion. None of us below retirement age now —whatever that is anymore — will ever retire, unless we were firemen, teachers or police officers with pensions —or wealthy. The regular Janes and Joes like me who work for ourselves? We're going work until we keel over. Retirement? Fuggedaboutit.

I am in my seventies and retirement has been very good to me. I would advise any young person to go into a profession that requires a license. That opens the strong possibility that one can work well into old age, on a part time basis, which makes saving a lot of money unnecessary. Also, don't forget about the spiritual side of life as our lives here on earth are very short. Jesus Christ, a very wise individual, says in the gospel of Matthew "What good will it be for you to gain the whole world, yet forfeit your soul?"
